questions.text: A 68-year-old smoker man with a history of hypertension presents to the ER with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. On examination, his pulse is irregularly irregular with a rate of 140 beats per minute. An ECG of the patient is given below. He has poorly controlled COPD. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?

choices.text: Multiple ectopic foci due to structural damage to heart
Start beta blockers followed by warfarin
CHADS2VASc score is used to decide the need for anticoagulation
Amiodarone is used for chemical cardioversion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start beta blockers followed by warfarin

 

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation of irregularly irregular pulse and ECG findings indicate atrial fibrillation. Beta blockers are contraindicated in asthma /COPD patients. For anticoagulation in non valvular causes start apixaban or dabigatran. Warfarin is used for RHD with mitral stenosis causing atrial fibrillation. Hence Option B is wrong.

CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk scoring system for AF

Points

Parameters

Score

C

Congestive heart failure

1

H

Hypertension history

1

A2

Age (≥75 years)

2

D

Diabetes mellitus

1

S2

Previous stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)

2

V

Vascular disease

1

A

Age (65-74 years)

1

Sc

Sex category (female)

1

 

Maximum total score

9 points

 

Management option for AF as per CHA2DS2-VASc score

  • 0: need not anticoagulate
  • 1: Give aspirin
  • >=2: Warfarin/Dabigatran/Rivaroxaban

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department in acute distress. He is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and complains of severe chest pain. BP is 90/60 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. Given the patient's condition, what is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Synchronized cardioversion

 

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation of acute distress, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and severe chest pain, along with the ECG showing saw-tooth flutter waves indicative of atrial flutter, suggests he is hemodynamically unstable. This necessitates immediate synchronized cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize his condition.

 

Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion.
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus.

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity).
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer presents to the emergency department with confusion and breathing difficulty. BP on admission is 80/60 mm Hg. The ECG is attached below. Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis in this patient? 



Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Cardiac tamponade

Explanation:
 

ECG shows low voltage with electrical alternans in V3–V6, II, III, aVF. BP is low, indicating cardiac tamponade. Precordial leads show J point elevation / Osborn waves that can be explained by hypercalcemia caused by breast carcinoma. All the remaining options will have normal to low BP, but hemodynamic instability favours the diagnosis as cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with confusion and muscle weakness. His laboratory results show a serum potassium level of 7.2 mEq/L.Which of the following T-wave morphologies is most likely to be seen on this patient's ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

Explanation:
In the setting of severe hyperkalemia (serum potassium > 7.0 mEq/L), the ECG typically shows peaked/tall T-waves, which is represented in Option C.

 

T-wave abnormalities:

 

T-wave Abnormality

Associated Conditions and Characteristics

Peaked T-waves


 

 
  • Hyperkalemia: Narrow, pointed, called tall tented T-waves
  • Myocardial infarction: Broad-based, asymmetric T-waves
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy: Tall T-waves in precordial leads
  • Prinzmetal angina: Tall, pointed T-waves during chest pain

Inverted T-waves
  • Myocardial ischemia: Symmetrically inverted T-waves
  • Wellens syndrome
  • Cerebrovascular injury: cerebral T-waves
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Pulmonary embolism in S1Q3T3

questions.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic presents to the emergency department with sweating and palpitations. He is a known case of T2DM on metformin and Glipizide. Labs show plasma glucose 65 mg/dl, serum creatinine 2.0 mg/dl, BUN 70 mg/dl and serum potassium of 5.8 meq/dl. ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Send nephro call for urgent hemodialysis
IV bolus of 25% dextrose with thiamine

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Send to cath lab

Explanation:

The ECG shows ST elevation in leads I, AVL, and V2-V5 & reciprocal depressions in the inferior leads (II, III, AVF). This is a case of anterior wall STEMI, and PCI should be done within 90 minutes of arrival at the hospital. After stabilisation based on eGFR value then the decision to continue or stop metformin will be made.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows a rapid, regular rhythm with a rate of 150 beats per minute, as shown below



Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia

Explanation:

The ECG shows a narrow qRS complex tachycardia seen in PSVT / AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia. The highlighted section in the ECG shows ST depression with P waves occurring after the RS complex. Rationale would be activation of atria after ventricles due to re-entry current. In most cases, these P waves may also not be seen.

Option A will have broad QRS tachycardia. Option C has delta waves and Option D has osborn waves.

 

Types of QRS Complex Abnormalities:

 

Type of QRS Complex

Associated Conditions

Narrow QRS complex Tachycardia

AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia, AV reentrant tachycardia (Orthodromic)

Broad QRS complex Tachycardia

Ventricular tachycardia, Torsades de Pointes

Delta Wave

Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome

J wave/Osbourne wave

Hypothermia

Epsilon wave

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

questions.text:
Match the following tachyarrhythmias with their respective pharmacological interventions

 


	
		
			
			Tachyarrhythmia
			
			
			Treatment
			
		
		
			
			1. Atrial Fibrillation in Hypertension
			
			
			A. Adenosine
			
		
		
			
			2. Stable Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia
			
			
			B. Esmolol followed by Anticoagulation
			
		
		
			
			3. Torsades de Pointes
			
			
			C. Magnesium Sulfate
			
		
		
			
			4. AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia
			
			
			D. Amiodarone
questions.solution:
Answer: A. 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

Initial treatment of long-standing atrial fibrillation is esmolol followed by oral anticoagulation. Stable VT is managed with Amiodarone. TDP with magnesium sulphate. AVNRT/ Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is managed with Adenosine.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the ER with palpitations and lightheadedness.She is on azithromycin and cough syrup by her GP. BP on admission is 100/60 mm Hg. Her ECG is given below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Administer intravenous magnesium sulfate

 

Explanation:

  • Key trigger is macrolides with over the counter cough syrups that may contain anti-histaminics like astemizole or terfenadine. This combination causes QT prolongation and triggers polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment for TdP, as it helps suppress the triggering PVCs and can shorten the QT interval.
  • Spindle-shaped pattern: The QRS complexes form a twisting or spindle-shaped "envelope."

Prolonged QT interval is the trigger for starting this arrhythmia.  

 

 

Causes of Polymorphic VT

Mnemonic: "A TIGERS BITE"

  • A - Antiarrhythmics (Class IA and III)
  • T - Tricyclic antidepressants
  • I - Ischemia (myocardial)
  • G - Genetics (congenital long QT syndrome)
  • E - Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia)
  • R - Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • S - Stroke (especially subarachnoid hemorrhage)
  • B - Bradycardia
  • I - Interactions (drug-drug interactions that prolong QT)
  • T - Toxins (organophosphates, arsenic, etc.)
  • E - Endocrine disorders (hypothyroidism, pheochromocytoma)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of prior myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with severe palpitations, dizziness, and chest pain. He suddenly becomes pulseless and BP is unrecordable. An ECG shows wide QRS complexes, a regular rhythm, and a ventricular rate of 160 bpm. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Defibrillation

Explanation:

This patient has pulseless/ unstable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) as indicated by the wide QRS complexes, regular rhythm, and associated symptoms (hypotension, chest pain, altered mental status). Hemodynamic instability in VT requires immediate defibrillation.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome?


	Accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles that lacks the decremental property
	Prolonged PR interval, delta waves, and narrow QRS complexes.
	Short PJ interval
	The drug of choice for an acute episode of palpitations is procainamide
questions.solution:
Answer: A. 1 and 4 only

Explanation:

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome has an accessory electrical pathway between the atria and ventricles, bypassing the AV node. This accessory pathway, also known as the Bundle of Kent. PR interval is short and hence option B is ruled out. PJ interval is normal so option C is ruled out. Procainamide is used for acute management of WPW

 

ECG features of WPW

  1. Short PR interval (<120 ms) due to rapid conduction through the accessory pathway
  2. Delta wave: a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex
  3. Widened QRS complex (>110 ms) due to the fusion of early (preexcited) and normal ventricular activation
  4. The PJ interval is normal

Fig: ECG in WPW Syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with sudden onset palpitations. ECG is shown below. You successfully terminated the arrhythmia using the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism by which this maneuver terminates the arrhythmia?

choices.text: Vagus induced decreased firing of the sinoatrial node
Vagus induced an increased sympathetic tone to the heart
Transient block in AV node conduction

questions.solution:
Answer: C. Transient block in AV node conduction

 

Explanation:

  • The Valsalva maneuver transiently increases intrathoracic pressure.
  • This leads to a reflex increase in vagal tone (parasympathetic activity).
  • Increased vagal tone affects the AV node, potentially causing a transient block in conduction of re-entry current responsible for PSVT.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic for a annual medical check-up. He has Hypertension and takes Ramipril and Amlodipine. Office BP recording is 124/ 80 mm Hg.  What is the ECG findings shown below? 



What is the most likely finding based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Normal sinus rhythm

 

Explanation:

 

LVH requires SV1 + RV5 > 35 mm which is not present. Second degree AV block has missed beats which are not present. RBBB has rSR pattern in lead V1 which is not seen. The interpretation by exclusion is normal sinus rhythm.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient is diagnosed with stokes adam syndrome. Which is correct about management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dual chamber pacemaker

 

Explanation:

Stokes adam syndrome has AV dissociation that leads to low cardiac output and increased risk of sudden cardiac death. Dual chamber pacemaker will cause restoration of AV synchrony and will improve cardiac output. It will ensure atrial contraction is followed by ventricular contraction to ensure normal hemodynamics. Option C and D are used for temporary pacing and are ruled out. The triple chamber pacemaker is called CRT ( cardiac resynchronization therapy) and is used in Dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 74-year-old patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent dizziness and lightheadedness. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, as shown below. Based on the ECG findings and the clinical scenario, what type of atrioventricular block is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mobitz Type II- infranodal

 

Explanation:

Notice a dropped beat (black arrow) after the second qRS complex. The P wave prior to it is visible, but QRS is missing. Now measure the PR interval after and before the missed beat, which is equal, and this indicates infranodal conduction defect. Also notice that each alternate P wave is not conducted down to ventricles indicating 2:1 block 

Third-degree AV Block shows complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no correlation between the two. First-degree heart block has a PR interval > 200 msec, and Mobitz I heart block shows serial prolongation of PR interval.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the ER due to sudden onset syncope in the bathroom. His medical history includes hypertension and a prior myocardial infarction. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Temporary pacing


 

 

Explanation:

The initial management for symptomatic bradycardia is Atropine. But atropine does not work if the lesion is below the level of the AV node. So temporary pacing is the initial treatment to be started.

ECG shows a huge difference between RR interval ( black arrows) and PP interval ( orange arrows). Ventricular rate is < 30 per min. There is complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes and the diagnosis is a third-degree atrioventricular block.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents to the ER with complaints of fatigue and occasional lightheadedness. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. During the examination, he describes episodes of near-syncope. The physician performs an ECG to evaluate his symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mobitz Type II

 

Explanation:

ECG shows a normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave, leading to dropped beats. This type is often associated with structural heart disease and can progress to complete heart block, which aligns with the patient’s symptoms and history.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an annual medical check up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) First-Degree AV Block

 

Explanation:

Solve this by exclusion. There are no dropped beats, so a second-degree heart block is ruled out. No of P waves is equal to the number of R waves, so a third-degree heart block is ruled out. BBB will have broad qRS complexes and ST segment changes that are not seen. So the answer is first-degree heart block that can be physiological. The PR interval in this ECG is 6 small squares, making it 240 msec.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent palpitations and dizziness. An ECG of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates
The accessory pathway is the Bundle of James, facilitating rapid conduction.
The ECG shows prolonged PR interval with delta waves
Adenosine is drug of choice for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates.

 

Explanation:

ECG shows delta waves and short PR intervals indicating WPW. The bypass tract lacks decremental property and runs the risk of conversion of atrial fibrillation to ventricular fibrillation.

James bundle is seen in Lown Ganong levine syndrome. DOC for WPW in acute episode management is procainamide and prevention of episodes is flecainide

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. He has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy. After a thorough examination, an ECG is obtained.



Based on the patient’s presentation and the findings of the ECG, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:B) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Check out precordial leads especially V4 that show a delta wave diagnostic of WPW. Option C and D cause bradycardia and are ruled out. Presence of P waves rules out atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is referred to your hospital for a suspected congenital heart condition due to central cyanosis. On examination, there is a prominent jugular venous pulsation and a pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows Himalayan P waves. Which condition will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Ebstein’s Anomaly

Explanation:

Key word is himalayan P waves/ Peaked P waves that indicate Right atrial enlargement. The presence of pansystolic murmur indicates regurgitation across the tricuspid valve. This is seen in Ebstein anomaly which has an inferior displacement of the tricuspid valve. The cyanosis is explained by R to L shunting across ASD or patent foramen ovale.

ASD and VSD are ruled out as they are acyanotic heart disease. TOGF has central cyanosis with ejection systolic murmur across the pulmonic valve.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with a one-month history of mild exertional dyspnea. She denies chest pain but has noticed some occasional palpitations. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and regular heart sounds. You order an ECG, which is shown below.



What is the most likely diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG in question shows left axis deviation when the vectors are plotted for the following data:

  • QRS is POSITIVE (dominant R wave) in Lead I
  • QRS is NEGATIVE (dominant S wave) in leads II, III and aVF

 

Normal Axis: QRS axis between -30° and +90°, points downward and slightly left.

Abnormal Axis Deviations:

  1. Left Axis Deviation: QRS axis less than -30°.
  2. Right Axis Deviation: QRS axis greater than +90°. 
  3. Extreme Axis Deviation: QRS axis between -90° and 180°.
